name: Acrocanthosaurus
description: Large bipedal carnivore, known for high neural spines forming a ridge down its back.
footprints: Large, 3-toed theropod tracks; famous trackways in Paluxy River, TX.
teeth: Curved, serrated, blade-like for slicing meat.
body_structures: High spines on vertebrae (muscle attachment or display), powerful arms, large skull.
coprolites: Rare; likely contained bone fragments given its diet.
other_info: State Dinosaur of Oklahoma; name means 'high-spined lizard'.
details:
Acrocanthosaurus was a large carnivorous theropod from the Early Cretaceous of North America (notably Oklahoma, Texas, and Arkansas). Its skeleton shows very tall neural spines forming a ridge along the back — the feature that gives it the name 'high-spined lizard'. Often reconstructed similar to Allosaurus but distinguished by the tall spinal ridge.

Quick facts:
- Time: Aptian–Albian (Early Cretaceous)
- Diet: Carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~7

name: Allosaurus
description: Large bipedal carnivore, the most common predator of the Late Jurassic.
teeth: Serrated, recurved, like steak knives; shed frequently.
body_structures: Two small horns above eyes, large powerful arms with 3 fingers.
other_info: Name means 'different lizard'; often called the 'Lion of the Jurassic'.
details:
Allosaurus was a large carnivorous theropod of the Late Jurassic, known from North America, Europe and Africa (fossils in Utah, Nebraska, Germany, etc.). Historically confused with the name Antrodemus, Allosaurus is now the standard name for well-documented specimens. It is commonly depicted with relatively long forelimbs and three-fingered hands; largest specimens reached around 30–32 ft.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Jurassic (approx. 163.5 Ma onward)
- Diet: Terrestrial carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~117

name: Ankylosaurus
description: Heavily armored quadrupedal herbivore, built like a living tank.
footprints: Rounded, 5-toed front, 4-toed hind; seldom preserved clearly.
teeth: Small, leaf-shaped, designed for cropping plants, not chewing.
body_structures: Osteoderms (bony armor), massive tail club, wide low body.
other_info: Last and largest of the ankylosaurs; tail club could shatter bone.
details:
Ankylosaurus was a heavily armored, squat quadruped herbivore from the Late Cretaceous of North America (Montana, Colorado, Alberta). It is famous for dense osteoderms and a reinforced tail club used in defence; modern reconstructions show a straighter hind-limb posture and a tail held higher than older art.

Quick facts:
- Time: Campanian → Maastrichtian (~83.5–66 Ma)
- Diet: Herbivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~14

name: Apatosaurus
footprints: Large, round/horseshoe-shaped front (1 claw), oval hind (3 claws).
teeth: Peg-like or pencil-like, only at the front of the jaw for stripping leaves.
body_structures: Long neck, whip-like tail, massive pillar-like legs.
coprolites: Large piles of plant material; rare.
other_info: Formerly known as Brontosaurus (though Brontosaurus is now considered valid by some, they are distinct genera).
details:
Apatosaurus was a large, long-necked sauropod herbivore from the Late Jurassic of North America (Utah, Texas, South Dakota). It had a long neck and massive pillar-like legs for a heavy, slow-moving browsing lifestyle; the name Brontosaurus was historically linked but recent work recognizes Brontosaurus as distinct in some analyses.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Jurassic (Tithonian and earlier)
- Diet: Herbivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~51

name: Archaeopteryx
teeth: Small, conical, sharp teeth (unlike modern birds).
body_structures: Feathers (flight and tail), wings with claws, long bony tail, wishbone.
coprolites: Small pellets containing insect or small lizard remains.
other_info: Transitional fossil between non-avian dinosaurs and birds; found in Germany.
details:
Archaeopteryx was a small, feathered theropod from the Late Jurassic of Germany, often cited as an early bird or close avian precursor. It had teeth and a long bony tail but also feathers and a wishbone; most evidence suggests short flights or gliding rather than sustained powered flight.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Jurassic (approx. 150 Ma)
- Diet: Insectivore/small prey; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~10

name: Coelophysis
body_structures: Hollow bones, long neck and tail, 4 fingers (only 3 functional).
coprolites: Found containing small reptile bones (debunking cannibalism theory).
other_info: State Fossil of New Mexico; thousands found together at Ghost Ranch.
details:
Coelophysis was a small, slender, early theropod (Triassic/Jurassic boundary) known from widespread remains including mass death assemblages (Ghost Ranch, NM). It was an agile, carnivorous predator with hollow bones and a lightweight build.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Triassic → Early Jurassic
- Diet: Carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: dozens (mass assemblages)

name: Deinonychus
footprints: 2-toed prints (walked on 3rd and 4th toes, 2nd toe held up).
body_structures: Large sickle-shaped claw on second toe, stiffened tail for balance, feathers.
other_info: Discovery sparked the 'Dinosaur Renaissance' (warm-blooded theory); inspired Jurassic Park 'raptors'.
details:
Deinonychus was a medium-sized, agile carnivorous theropod from the Early Cretaceous of North America (Montana, Colorado, Wyoming). Famous for its sickle-shaped second toe claw and bird-like features, Deinonychus helped shift views toward active, possibly warm-blooded dinosaurs.

Quick facts:
- Time: Early Cretaceous (approx. 115–100 Ma)
- Diet: Carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~41

name: Diplodocus
footprints: Large, round front, oval hind; often no tail drag marks.
teeth: Peg-like, forward-pointing, only at front of mouth.
body_structures: Extremely long whip-like tail, long neck, spines along back.
other_info: One of the longest dinosaurs; tail tip could potentially break the sound barrier.
details:
Diplodocus was a very long, slender sauropod herbivore from the Late Jurassic of North America (Utah, New Mexico, South Dakota). It is known for a long neck and whip-like tail with double-beamed chevrons on the underside of the tail.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Jurassic (Tithonian)
- Diet: Herbivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~60

name: Iguanodon
description: Large, bulky herbivore that could walk on 2 or 4 legs.
footprints: 3-toed, broad, blunt claws; often handprints found nearby.
teeth: Leaf-shaped with serrated edges, similar to an iguana.
body_structures: Conical thumb spike, horny beak, ossified tendons in tail.
other_info: One of the first three dinosaurs named; thumb spike was originally mistaken for a nose horn.
details:
Iguanodon was a large, often bipedal herbivore from the Early Cretaceous of Europe; notable for a conical thumb spike and dental batteries for processing plant material. Early discoveries and mass finds helped shape early paleontology.

Quick facts:
- Time: Early Cretaceous
- Diet: Herbivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: 100+

name: Parasaurolophus
description: Duck-billed herbivore (hadrosaur) with a distinctive crest.
footprints: 3-toed, broad, blunt; similar to other hadrosaurs.
teeth: Dental batteries containing hundreds of grinding teeth.
body_structures: Long, tubular crest extending backward from skull, duck-like bill.
other_info: Crest was hollow and likely used as a resonating chamber for making sounds.
details:
Parasaurolophus was a large duck-billed hadrosaur of the Late Cretaceous, recognized by its long, tubular cranial crest which may have been used for display or sound production. It could walk on two or four legs and had broad dental batteries for grinding plants.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Cretaceous (approx. 83–70 Ma)
- Diet: Herbivore
- Known specimens: ~17

name: Plateosaurus
description: Bipedal prosauropod herbivore; ancestor to giant sauropods.
teeth: Leaf-shaped, serrated, for shredding tough plants.
body_structures: Long neck, strong tail, large thumb claw, small head.
other_info: One of the first large dinosaurs; often found in mass accumulations in Europe.
details:
Plateosaurus was an early, bipedal prosauropod herbivore from the Triassic of Europe; abundant fossils make it a key species for studying early dinosaur evolution.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Triassic
- Diet: Herbivore
- Known specimens: ~33

name: Stegosaurus
description: Large herbivore with plates and tail spikes.
teeth: Small, triangular, flat, leaf-shaped; weak chewing ability.
body_structures: Two rows of bony plates on back, four spikes on tail (thagomizer).
other_info: Brain was the size of a walnut; plates likely for display or thermoregulation.
details:
Stegosaurus was a plated herbivore of the Late Jurassic, famous for two rows of bony plates along its back and a spiked tail (thagomizer) for defence. Plate function is debated (display vs thermoregulation).

Quick facts:
- Time: Upper Jurassic → Lower Cretaceous
- Diet: Herbivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~75

name: Triceratops
footprints: 5-toed front, 4-toed hind; resembles giant rhino tracks.
teeth: Dental batteries with shearing teeth for tough vegetation.
body_structures: Three horns (two brow, one nose), large bony frill, parrot-like beak.
other_info: State Fossil of South Dakota; frill likely used for display or defense against T. rex.
details:
Triceratops was a large, three-horned quadrupedal herbivore of the Late Cretaceous in North America, instantly recognizable by its brow horns and large frill used for display and defense. It likely used horns in combat with predators and conspecifics.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian)
- Diet: Herbivore
- Known specimens: ~139

name: Tyrannosaurus rex
teeth: Thick, banana-shaped, serrated, designed to crush bone.
body_structures: Tiny two-fingered arms, massive skull, binocular vision.
coprolites: Famous coprolites found containing pulverized bone fragments.
other_info: Had the strongest bite force of any land animal; name means 'Tyrant Lizard King'.
details:
Tyrannosaurus rex was a massive apex predator of the Late Cretaceous in North America, with powerful jaws and serrated teeth adapted for crushing bone. One of the best-known dinosaurs, T. rex is central to studies of predatory behavior and biomechanics.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian)
- Diet: Apex carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: many

name: Velociraptor
body_structures: Sickle claw on second toe, feathers, long stiff tail, long skull.
other_info: Actually the size of a turkey (much smaller than in movies); famous 'Fighting Dinosaurs' fossil.
details:
Velociraptor was a small, agile dromaeosaurid theropod from the Late Cretaceous of Asia (Mongolia), with feathers, a long tail, and a sickle-shaped toe claw. Popular culture often exaggerates its size; the real animal was roughly turkey-sized.

Quick facts:
- Time: Late Cretaceous
- Diet: Carnivore; reproduced by laying eggs
- Known specimens: ~18
